subject: Narrow expected responses for CheckUserInGroup
commit_message:
Narrow expected responses for CheckUserInGroup

When checking whether a given user is in a given group, keystone will
return a 404 Not Found if all went well but the user was not in the
group. It may also return a 403 if the user and the group are in
different backends, which would also mean that the user was not in the
group[1]. Any other 400 response is a client error and any 500 response
is a server error to which the user should be alerted.

Without this patch, openstackclient treats any exception as a valid "not
found" and may end up hiding server errors. This patch reduces the
caught exceptions to 403 and 404 responses and treats everything else as
an error.

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/?expanded=check-whether-user-belongs-to-group-detail#check-whether-user-belongs-to-group

Closes-bug: #1672634

subject: Add Flask-SQLAlchemy to requirements for Nemesis
commit_message:
Add Flask-SQLAlchemy to requirements for Nemesis

- Actively Maintained?
  Yes, Pocoo are actively maintaining this package with regular
  releases to PyPi.

- Good code?
  Looks pretty good to me, currently tested via Travis and the
  tox coverage is very comprehensive.

- Python 3 compatable?
  Sure is, I have used this previously with 2.6, 2.7, 3.4 and 3.5

- License?
  BSD

- Packaged as part of targetted distros?
  Ubuntu - Yes
  Fedora - Yes

- Is the functionality already covered?
  Kind of, most of this stuff does the same kind of thing as Oslo.Db,
  however Oslo.DB does not have the integration with the Flask
  extension framework like Flask-SQLAlchemy. For our project it would
  be really great to use Flask-SQLAlchemy initially and then deprecate
  it later once we have made a Flask extension for Oslo.DB, so far
  we have already created a Flask extension for Oslo.Log and reasonable
  wrapper code for Oslo.Config. So, for now yes this does add additional
  functionality compared to Oslo.DB alone, long term I'd like to
  deprecate using Flask-SQLAlchemy though in favour of a Flask-OsloDB
  extension.

- Which project is this for?
  We are using Flask heavily within the Nemesis project to create our
  web service. Currently we are using Flask-SQLAlchemy as Oslo.DB
  is not currently available in the form of a Flask extension. For
  now our CI fails as we are opted into the global reqs sync job.

Read instances from API cell for cells v1

Recent work on cells v2 has us reading instances from compute cells
via target_cell, but that breaks the existing behavior of cells v1
because of the syncing between API cell and compute cells. When
state changes are effected in the API cell, there is a slight delay
before they are reflected in the compute cell. So, reading from the
compute cell instead of the API cell results in behavior changes.

This adds a conditional in compute/api get_all to read instances
from the API cell if cells v1 is enabled. We are already doing this
for compute/api get, and get_all was missed.

subject: Create profile to request certificates for the services in the node
commit_message:
Create profile to request certificates for the services in the node

This profile will specifically be used to create all the certificates
required in the node. These are fetched from hiera and will be ran in
the first step of the overcloud deployment and in the undercloud.

The reasoning for this is that, with services moving to containers, we
can't yet do these requests for certificates within the containers for
the specific services. this is because the containers won't have
credentials to the CA, while the baremetal node does. So instead we
still do this on the baremetal node, and will subsequently bind mount
the certificates to the containers that need them. Also, this gives us
flexibility since this approach still works for the baremetal case.

There will be a subsequent commit removing the certificate requests from
the service-specific profiles.

Change-Id: I4d2e62b5c1b893551f9478cf5f69173c334ac81f

subject: Explain how allow_resize_to_same_host is useful
commit_message:
Explain how allow_resize_to_same_host is useful

With the ServerGroupAffinityFilter enabled, you need to also set
allow_resize_to_same_host to True. Mentioning this in the
description for that config setting.

ServerGroupAffinity is a scheduler setting that places all
servers with the group on the same host. (It is the opposite
of AntiAffinity that PREVENTS them from being on the same
host.) Consequently, if you try to resize a server that is
in an Affinity group (ie, it is affined) it will fail as the
current rules IMMEDIATELY remove the current server from
the list of possible scheduling targets (unless you have enabled
"allow_resize_to_same_host".) Since none of the other servers
can be candidates because of the Affinity rule, the resize
fails entirely.

Change-Id: I77a90ffdfe465d99ee8596375430ee960048d566
Closes-Bug: #1660090

in function-libvirt.  We only install the qemu-kvm-ev package on
centos and remove the old work-around.

Ironic already exposes heartbeat endpoint in top-level,
driver-independent REST API.

script/startup job than whole Ironic Python Agent inside the deploy ramdisk,
let us allow out-of-tree drivers which are not IPA-based to re-use
base ironic heartbeat processing implementation as is.

This patch moves the 'heartbeat' method to a separate HeartbeatMixin
class, and also provides dummy implementations of methods called from

functionality may inherit from this class and override self._client in
their __init__ to None or False to suppress collecting logs from
ramdisk on failure.

subject: placement: ironic inventory reporting
commit_message:
placement: ironic inventory reporting

This patch adds a new virt driver API method called get_inventory() that
takes the nodename as a parameter and returns a dict, keyed by resource
class, of inventory information. The only virt driver that has an
implementation of the new get_inventory() method is the Ironic virt
driver, which, in this patch, returns both the legacy VCPU, MEMORY_MB
and DISK_GB resource classes as well as the new custom resource class
for the Ironic node, if present.

The resource tracker's _update() method was modified to first call the
virt driver get_inventory() method to get a Placement-aligned dictionary
of inventory/resource information and call a new
set_inventory_for_provider() method on the scheduler reporting client.
If the get_inventory() method is not implemented by the virt driver,
then the resource tracker falls back to calling the existing
update_resource_stats() scheduler reporting client method which analyses
the compute node object and constructs an inventory dict that the
placement API understands.

For Ironic, because of the contract we have with the Ironic team, this
code auto-creates custom resource classes that come in from the Ironic
virt driver from the node's resource_class attribute. For all other
drivers, we do not auto-create resource classes in the placement API.

Note that we DO NOT yet *consume* the custom resource class inventory
during instance_claim() against an Ironic node. Once flavors are
modified to have the "resources:$CUSTOM_RESOURCE_CLASS=1" extra spec and
the scheduler will construct a request to consume *only* the custom
resource class, at that point we will correct the allocation records for
Ironic resource providers.

subject: Fix multipath flush when using friendly names
commit_message:
Fix multipath flush when using friendly names

When we are using friendly names for multipath the multipaths are not
getting flushed, which may lead to data loss on slow connections and
multipath entries with no actual paths.

This happens in both iSCSI and FC connections, and it is due to the
flush being requested on the WWN instead of the actual name of the
device.

So when we are not using friendly names the WWN and the device name are
the same and our call to multipath -f will successfully flush remaining
data, but when we are using friendly names they will not match, and the
call to multipath -f will silently fail (return code 0) and the flush
will not actually go through. When the flush doesn't happen, if there is
remaining data, then the multipath will stay once the individual paths
have been removed.

Closes-Bug: #1663925

subject: RBD driver doesn't flatten image when clone depth > configured value.
commit_message:
RBD driver doesn't flatten image when clone depth > configured value.

RBD driver has a rbd_max_clone_depth config option which would trigger
image flatten operation when a RBD image has been chain-cloned to that
value.  But the driver only trigger flatten when actual clone depth
equals rbd_max_clone_depth.  There are cases where actual clone depth
is bigger than rbd_max_clone_depth (for example: admin somehow changed
rbd_max_clone_depth from a bigger value to a smaller value),
auto-flatten won't be triggered.  This change allows RBD driver to
flatten image has been cloned >= rbd_max_clone_depth.

Closes-Bug: #1644129

Change-Id: Ic6e62ffcb4aded6ee9a652a1f4d0a1db5eac0ceb

subject: Fix iSCSI multipath rescan
commit_message:
Fix iSCSI multipath rescan

iSCSI multipath rescan uses iscsiadm --rescan option for nodes and
sessions, which can end up recreating devices that had just been removed
if there's a race condition between the removal of a SCSI device and the
connection of a volume.

The race condition happens if a rescan done when attaching happens right
between us removing the path and removing the exported lun, because the
rescan will add not only the new path we are attaching, but the old path
we are removing, since the lun still hasn't been removed.

This would leave orphaned devices that unnecessarily pollute our
environment,

This patch narrows the rescan to only rescan for the specific target id,
channel, and lun number if we can find this information.

When we cannot find this information we do the scan as we were doing it
before.

Closes-Bug: #1664032
Change-Id: I1b3bd34db260165a6ea9ca061f946d6dfcf8553f

subject: Workaround for unmatching scheme in discovery
commit_message:
Workaround for unmatching scheme in discovery

when doing keystone discovery, there are issues returning the scheme in
specific scenarios: e.g. when keystone is deployed behind a TLS proxy,
and oslo.middleware's http_proxy_to_wsgi is not available.

To workaround this, we could remember the original scheme that was given
as the auth_url, and try to use that in case the URL gotten via
discovery is not working.

Even though this scenario is a common misconfiguration of the
loadbalancer and keystone. This is unfortunately a very common issue.
So working around this in keystoneclient seems like the best way to go,
as it will ease the transition for moving services to use discovery and
not rely on versioned endpoints.

The original patch where this was discussed is this one:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/443104/

Change-Id: I1ee828215d0a0184474021d6236c2bc234af5176
